column4: What is the cpu load for an idle Windows guest running in VirtualBox? I'm getting 20-25% and a load of >1.2
What is the usual cpu load*
really depends on what processes are running in the background in winodws
an idle windows, with no strange stuff running in the background, should be quite minimal
absolutely no user app is running in the background. Just the win services, with the updates disabled
and the task manager (in windows) shows low usage?
correct.
do you have multiple cores, like a dual core or the amd phenom, also, do you have virtualization (in the processor) turned on in the virtual box configs?
no, a single core 3.8 GHz pentium
ah, single core uses *much* more of the processor, and the lack of virtualization routines
the processor is having to work very hard; you would notice a huge difference by upgrading your proc marginally to a dual core
not without changing the mobo as well. I believe the problem to be a software one as the reverse case (linux guest in windows host) gives me normal idle usage.
then ea. os (linux and windows) would have their own proc to use, thereby significantly increasing the stability and operation of ea. os
we're talking about 3.8 billion operations a second. I think that's plenty for each :)
forgive me, but i would much prefer a quad core 2.0 gighz to a 3.8 ghz any day
particularly in linux since it actually uses all the cores ;)
i'm sorry, but I'
m all out of ideas.  perhaps it's something to do with video... are you using a 3d card, or a vesa card, and vice versa w/ drivers
3D accel is disabled in the guest. I actually think it's the net driver VB uses.
not in the guest, in linux; the reason i say this, is that it seems likely that virtual box is having to do some additional emulation for something it generally doesn't
like having to do extra work drawing the window, accessing the hard drive, ram, etc...
I have 3D up and running, with 64 MB reserved for the guest.
perhaps windows is wasting a lot of processor operations with a swap file, do you know if windows is using one... 64mb is not very much!
64MB video RAM is plenty. The recommended amount is below 32. Disk IO in the guest is minimal/absent. I really do believe this is a host issue.
